{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3548789,"name":"Sorin Schiefelbein","username":"sorinschief","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T00:19:33.842Z","cooked":"

I have two NEOs on my elevator and I would like to move it to a position and hold it at a position. I set config.idleMode(SparkBaseConfig.IdleMode.kBrake) on my SparkMaxConfig, but when I start to move it up (.set(0.25)) and then set it to 0, nothing seems to happen and it just slides back down, and I’m not sure why.

I’ve never used WPILib or REVLib before so sorry if I’m missing something that should be obvious.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-03-06T00:19:33.842Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":73,"readers_count":72,"score":84.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":494424,"topic_slug":"holding-braking-a-spark-max-controller","display_username":"Sorin Schiefelbein","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71514,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/holding-braking-a-spark-max-controller/494424/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3548793,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T00:27:18.140Z","cooked":"

You can think of brake mode as “drag mode”. It won’t hold position if there is a force beyond static friction.

It effectively just shorts the windings in the motor, the resistance you feel is those shorted windings fighting against the magnets in the motor (back EMF). There is more to it than that, but I hope you get the idea.

Mechanically you can counterbalance your mechanism (gas shocks, constant force springs)

Code wise there is not much you can do when the robot is disabled.

If the robot is enabled, a PID controller should be able to hold position, beyond that you may be pouted to PIDF controllers (PID + feed forward).
